paragraphs.text: Solid State Communications Comparative studies of magnetic and magnetocaloric properties in amorphous Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 films
Amorphous Gd 0.67 × 0.3 (X=Y, Zr) films were grown by RF sputtering and their magnetic and magnetocaloric properties were studied.

The magnetic properties were found to be improved in case of Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 with respect to Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33, in which the Curie temperature, magnetization and spin wave stiffness were higher for Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 , which we attribute to its larger Gd-Gd distance.
The temperature dependence of magnetic entropy change (−ΔS M ) was calculated from the isothermal magnetization.

Under a magnetic field change of 3 T, (−ΔS M ) were found to be 2.14 and 1.12 J/kg K, with corresponding relative cooling power (RCP) of 198.86 and 113.2 J/ kg, for Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 , respectively.
The larger magnetocaloric properties for Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 are attributed to its higher magnetization.
Amorphous Gd-alloys, Spin wave Magnetocaloric effect Magnetic entropy change Magnetic transition, Relative cooling power
Magnetic refrigeration is an attractive technology due to its high efficiency, and ecological compatibility.
The magnetocaloric effect (MCE) is at the basis of this application, which involves a change in temperature of a magnetic material upon the application of a magnetic field .
In general, the magnetocaloric effect is determined by the magnetic entropy change (−ΔS M ), and adiabatic temperature change (ΔT ad ) under a magnetic field change (ΔH).
These parameters are essential to achieve high magnetic refrigeration efficiency .
During last years, intense research activities were devoted to develop new magnetocaloric materials with large (−ΔS M ) and ΔT ad .
One can notice that most of the efforts were previously dedicated to study first- order magnetic transition (FOMT) materials, because of their high (−ΔS M ).

However, FOMTs occur in a narrow temperature window and are often accompanied with some non-desirable effects such as: irreversibility of the effect, poor mechanical thermal stability or field hysteresis .

It is known that magnetic materials with a second-order phase transition (SOMT) lack a very large (−ΔS M ), but they do present a very high refrigeration capacity (RC), which is now recognized as a key parameter for achieving high magnetic refrigeration efficiency .
The other positive advantages of SOMT materials are low magnetic hysteresis, higher electrical resistivity, enhanced corrosion resistance, and tunable T C by varying the composition .
Gadolinium (Gd) and its alloys undergo a SOMT, which make them interesting for magnetic refrigeration.
Alloying Gd with Y, Zr offers an advantage due to their similar crystal structure with close lattice parameters.
Nevertheless, despite the interesting properties of the Gd-(Y, Zr) alloys, all magnetocaloric studies report solely on bulk or crystalline film phases and never in amorphous state.
Here, we compare both the magnetic and magnetocaloric properties of amorphous Gd 0.67 (Y, Zr) 0.33 films.
Amorphous Gd 0.67 × 0.33 (X=Y, Zr) films were deposited on glass substrates using composite targets and RF sputtering system.
The starting vacuum was 10 −7 Torr.
The used gas during sputtering was Argon of 5N purity.

The argon pressure during growth was fixed at 6×10 −3 Torr, while the RF power was in the range 80-100 W. Water cooled were used during growth to cool down the substrate to stabilize an amorphous state of the samples.
Magnetization measurements were carried out using extraction method with an applied external field up to 5 T and in the temperature range of 4.2-220 K [10].
The temperature dependence of magnetization recorded at a magnetic field of 0.5 T for amorphous Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 thin films are shown in .
The M(T) curves were recorded in field cooling (FC) mode.
The samples were cooled down from high to low temperature in the presence of the applied magnetic field and then the measurements were carried out in warming mode from low to high temperature .
As can be observed in the figure, both samples show a decrease in magnetization with increasing temperature, which is typical for a ferromagnetic behavior .

In order to determine the Curie temperature (T C ), we display in the inset of The T C is defined as the inflection point of derivative and it is determined to be 70 and 60 K for Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 respectively.
These results show that the Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 alloy exhibits higher T C than that of Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 .
We note that the effective moments of Gd (μ ) eff Gd deduced from Curie Weiss law were found to be 7.99 µ B and 7.92 µ B for Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 , respectively.
For ferromagnetic materials, the temperature dependence of mag- netization M (T) follows Block's law (T 3/2 ) which is associated to the thermal excitation of spin waves .

According to the spin wave theory, the M (T) curves of ferromagnetic materials can be expressed using the following formula: Where B is the spin-wave constant, µ B is the Bohr magneton, k B is the Boltzman constant, D is the spin wave stiffness and g is the Landé factor.
Eq.
(1) is a good estimate of low-temperature magnetization for crystalline and amorphous ferromagnetic materials .
shows the variation of magnetization as a function of T 3/2 recorded at a field of 5 T for both alloys.
As can be observed, Eq.
(1) fits well the low temperature data.
The linear fit (solid lines in ) of the experi- mental data permits to determine the B parameter using Eq.
(1), which is defined as the slope of the M vs. T 3/2 curve.
Finally, the use of the obtained B values and Eq.
(2) allows to determine the exchange stiffness constant D .
As can be observed in , the D parameter is found to be larger for the Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 alloy highlighting that the ferromagnetic interaction is higher for this alloy.
This is in agreement with the results described above (T C is higher for Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 ).
The increase of the ferromagnetic interaction for the Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 alloy can be understood by its longer Gd-Gd interatomic distance due to the larger Y atomic radii with respect to Zr.
This larger Gd-Gd interatomic distance should shift the magnetic interaction from antiferromagnetic to ferromagnetic .
Due to the random distribution of the Gd-Gd distances within the amorphous matrix, the magnetic interaction is not homogenous.
At short Gd-Gd dis- tances, the exchange interaction is antiferromagnetic and at large Gd- Gd distances the ferromagnetic interaction is dominant.
However, the presence of well-defined T C indicates that the ferromagnetic interaction is dominant.
To estimate the Gd-Gd interatomic distance, we utilize the Heisenberg model.
We note that the Heisenberg model can describe the systems presenting localized electrons .
The magnetism in gadoli- nium (Gd) is related to the 4 f bands, which are strongly localized.
Therefore, we can safely apply the Heisenberg model for the system studied here.
According to Heisenberg model, D and T C can be expressed as: Where r Gd-Gd is the distance between nearest magnetic atoms (Gd) and S Gd is the spin moment of the Gd atom.
Using Eq.
(3), we have determined the r Gd-Gd to be about 3.63 and 3.7 Å for Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 , respectively.
These results support that the increase of the ferromagnetic interaction is associated with the larger Gd-Gd intera- tomic distance for Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 .

From the coefficient D mentioned above, it is possible to calculate the exchange constant A. We note that A and D are related as: All the extracted parameters obtained using spin wave theory are listed in .
In order to study the magnetocaloric effect in our samples, we have carried out isothermal magnetization curves recorded at different temperatures [and (b)].
As shown for both Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 alloys, a progressive decrease of magnetization with a linear variation can be seen with increasing temperature, which is due
Change of the magnetization as a function of temperature of the amorphous Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 films.
The measurements were recorded at an applied magnetic field of 0.5 T. The inset shows the corresponding |dM/dT| vs. T plot.
Change of the magnetization as a function of T 3/2 of the amorphous Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 films.
The measurements were carried out under an applied field of 5 T.
Comparison of the parameters extracted using spin wave theory for amorphous Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 alloys.
to the ferromagnetic to paramagnetic transition in the vicinity of T C .
We note that the magnetization of Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 is higher than that of Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 .
At a temperature of 4.2 K and for an applied field of 5 T, the magnetizations are found to be 120 and 90 emu/g for the Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 samples, respectively.
This shows that Y induces better magnetic properties than Zr.
One can notice that the magnetization of samples does not saturate even at a field up to 5 T, which can be explained by the existence of antiferromagnetic interac- tions.
Using Maxwell relation, (-ΔS M ) can be calculated from the iso- thermal magnetization curves in the vicinity of T C .
From the thermo- dynamic theory, the magnetic entropy change caused by the change of the external magnetic field from 0 to H max can be expressed as:

In case of discrete change of applied fields, we use the following formula : Where M i and M i+1 are the experimental values of magnetization at temperatures Ti and T i+1 under an applied magnetic field H i, respec- tively .
The results of the temperature dependence of (-ΔS M ) for Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 are displayed in .
For both alloys, (-ΔS M ) increases with increasing temperature to reach a broad maximum around T C .
The caret-like shape of the (-ΔS M )(T) curves shows that the magnetic transition near T C is a second-order phase transition.
It is observed that the value of (-ΔS M ) for Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 is higher than that of Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 .
For a field change of 3 T, (-ΔS M ) are found to be 2.14 and 1.12 J/kg.
K, for Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 alloys, respectively.
The larger value of of (-ΔS M ) for the Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 alloy can be understood by its larger magnetization with respect to Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 .
Note that a large (-ΔS M ) is not enough to obtain excellent magnetic refrigeration features.
The effective method for characterizing the cooling efficiency is the RCP which is defined as: Where δT FWHM is the full width at half-maximum of the (-ΔS M )(T) curve .

The RCP of a magnetic material is a measure of how much heat is transferred between the hot and cold ends in one ideal refrigeration cycle and it is an important parameter as far as the magnetic cooling is concerned.
The changes of RCP as function of the applied magnetic field for the amorphous Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 alloys are shown in .
As can be observed for both samples, the RCP increases with increasing magnetic field.
(-ΔS M ) spans over a wide temperature window.
Under a field change of 3 T, δT FWHM are about 92.88 and 100.08 K, with corresponding RCP values of 198.86 and 113.2 J/kg for Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 alloys, respectively.
Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 alloy exhibits a larger RCP than Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 due to its higher (-ΔS M ).
Thus, we can conclude that the Gd-Y alloys present

(a) Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and
(b) Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 films.

Magnetic entropy changes as a function of temperature of the amorphous Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 films obtained at a magnetic field change of 3 T. 0.0 0.5 1.0 1.5 2.0 2.5 3.0 3.5 Change of the relative cooling power (RCP) as a function of the applied field for amorphous Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 alloys.
better magnetocaloric performance than Gd-Zr.
In summary, the magnetic and magnetocaloric properties of amorphous Gd 0.67 (Y, Zr) 0.33 alloys were studied.
Magnetic measure- ments have shown the existence of a ferromagnetic order with Curie temperature of 70 and 60 K for Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 respec- tively.
The spin wave theory allowed us to find that the ferromagnetic interactions are stronger for the Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 due to its longer Gd-Gd interatomic distance.
For a magnetic field change of 3 T, Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 and Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 have a maximum magnetic entropy value of 2.141 and 1.12 J/kg K, with RCP values of 198.86 and 113.2J/kg, respectively.
Finally, our comparison shows that Gd 0.67 Y 0.33 is more interesting than Gd 0.67 Zr 0.33 for achieving both good magnetic and magnetocaloric properties.
